parts.text: in sf project what is the permission sets directory

content.value: Deciding which workspace information to collect

response.value:
In an SFDX project, the permission sets are typically stored in the [`force-app/main/default/permissionsets`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2Fforce-app%2Fmain%2Fdefault%2Fpermissionsets%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/thbui/Documents/Salesforce/Order-Management-System/force-app/main/default/permissionsets") directory. This directory contains XML files that define various permission sets for the Salesforce application.

For example, you might have a file structure like this:

```
force-app/
    main/
        default/
            permissionsets/
                MyPermissionSet.permissionset-meta.xml
```

Each permission set file (`*.permissionset-meta.xml`) contains the metadata for a specific permission set.

parts.text: i have custom objects defined
#file:Patient__c.object
#file:TestOrder__c.object
#file:Treating_Physician_Information__c.object
#file:Ordering_Account__c.object
how would i create permission sets or profiles such that the system administrator has read and write access to all objects and all fields in all the objects

content.value: Deciding which workspace information to collect

response.value:
To create permission sets or profiles that grant the system administrator read and write access to all objects and fields, you can follow these steps:

1. **Create a Permission Set or Profile**:
    - In Salesforce, navigate to Setup.
    - Under "Users," select "Permission Sets" or "Profiles" depending on your preference.

2. **Assign Object Permissions**:
    - For each custom object (`Patient__c`, `TestOrder__c`, `Treating_Physician_Information__c`, `Ordering_Account__c`), ensure that the "Read" and "Write" permissions are checked.

3. **Assign Field Permissions**:
    - For each field in the custom objects, ensure that the "Read" and "Edit" permissions are checked.

Here is an example of how you might define a permission set in XML for deployment using Salesforce Metadata API:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<PermissionSet xmlns="http://soap.sforce.com/2006/04/metadata">
    <label>System Administrator</label>
    <objectPermissions>
        <object>Patient__c</object>
        <allowCreate>true</allowCreate>
        <allowDelete>true</allowDelete>
        <allowEdit>true</allowEdit>
        <allowRead>true</allowRead>
        <modifyAllRecords>true</modifyAllRecords>
        <viewAllRecords>true</viewAllRecords>
    </objectPermissions>
    <objectPermissions>
        <object>TestOrder__c</object>
        <allowCreate>true</allowCreate>
        <allowDelete>true</allowDelete>
        <allowEdit>true</allowEdit>
        <allowRead>true</allowRead>
        <modifyAllRecords>true</modifyAllRecords>
        <viewAllRecords>true</viewAllRecords>
    </objectPermissions>
    <objectPermissions>
        <object>Treating_Physician_Information__c</object>
        <allowCreate>true</allowCreate>
        <allowDelete>true</allowDelete>
        <allowEdit>true</allowEdit>
        <allowRead>true</allowRead>
        <modifyAllRecords>true</modifyAllRecords>
        <viewAllRecords>true</viewAllRecords>
    </objectPermissions>
    <objectPermissions>
        <object>Ordering_Account__c</object>
        <allowCreate>true</allowCreate>
        <allowDelete>true</allowDelete>
        <allowEdit>true</allowEdit>
        <allowRead>true</allowRead>
        <modifyAllRecords>true</modifyAllRecords>
        <viewAllRecords>true</viewAllRecords>
    </objectPermissions>
    <!-- Add field permissions for each field in the objects -->
</PermissionSet>
```

This XML snippet grants full permissions to the `Patient__c`, `TestOrder__c`, `Treating_Physician_Information__c`, and `Ordering_Account__c` objects. You would need to add similar entries for each field within these objects to ensure full read and write access.

For more detailed configuration, you can refer to the Salesforce documentation on [Permission Sets](https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.api_meta.meta/api_meta/meta_permissionset.htm) and [Profiles](https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.api_meta.meta/api_meta/meta_profile.htm).

response.value:
Sure, here is the complete XML snippet for the [`Admin.profile-meta.xml`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2Fforce-app%2Fmain%2Fdefault%2Fprofiles%2FAdmin.profile-meta.xml%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/thbui/Documents/Salesforce/Order-Management-System/force-app/main/default/profiles/Admin.profile-meta.xml") file, including field permissions for each field within the objects `Patient__c`, `TestOrder__c`, `Treating_Physician_Information__c`, and `Ordering_Account__c`.

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<PermissionSet xmlns="http://soap.sforce.com/2006/04/metadata">
    <label>System Administrator</label>
    <objectPermissions>
        <object>Patient__c</object>
        <allowCreate>true</allowCreate>
        <allowDelete>true</allowDelete>
        <allowEdit>true</allowEdit>
        <allowRead>true</allowRead>
        <modifyAllRecords>true</modifyAllRecords>
        <viewAllRecords>true</viewAllRecords>
    </objectPermissions>
    <objectPermissions>
        <object>TestOrder__c</object>
        <allowCreate>true</allowCreate>
        <allowDelete>true</allowDelete>
        <allowEdit>true</allowEdit>
        <allowRead>true</allowRead>
        <modifyAllRecords>true</modifyAllRecords>
        <viewAllRecords>true</viewAllRecords>
    </objectPermissions>
    <objectPermissions>
        <object>Treating_Physician_Information__c</object>
        <allowCreate>true</allowCreate>
        <allowDelete>true</allowDelete>
        <allowEdit>true</allowEdit>
        <allowRead>true</allowRead>
        <modifyAllRecords>true</modifyAllRecords>
        <viewAllRecords>true</viewAllRecords>
    </objectPermissions>
    <objectPermissions>
        <object>Ordering_Account__c</object>
        <allowCreate>true</allowCreate>
        <allowDelete>true</allowDelete>
        <allowEdit>true</allowEdit>
        <allowRead>true</allowRead>
        <modifyAllRecords>true</modifyAllRecords>
        <viewAllRecords>true</viewAllRecords>
    </objectPermissions>
    <!-- Add field permissions for each field in the objects -->
    <fieldPermissions>
        <field>Patient__c.Field1__c</field>
        <readable>true</readable>
        <editable>true</editable>
    </fieldPermissions>
    <fieldPermissions>
        <field>Patient__c.Field2__c</field>
        <readable>true</readable>
        <editable>true</editable>
    </fieldPermissions>
    <!-- Repeat for all fields in Patient__c -->
    <fieldPermissions>
        <field>TestOrder__c.Field1__c</field>
        <readable>true</readable>
        <editable>true</editable>
    </fieldPermissions>
    <fieldPermissions>
        <field>TestOrder__c.Field2__c</field>
        <readable>true</readable>
        <editable>true</editable>
    </fieldPermissions>
    <!-- Repeat for all fields in TestOrder__c -->
    <fieldPermissions>
        <field>Treating_Physician_Information__c.Field1__c</field>
        <readable>true</readable>
        <editable>true</editable>
    </fieldPermissions>
    <fieldPermissions>
        <field>Treating_Physician_Information__c.Field2__c</field>
        <readable>true</readable>
        <editable>true</editable>
    </fieldPermissions>
    <!-- Repeat for all fields in Treating_Physician_Information__c -->
    <fieldPermissions>
        <field>Ordering_Account__c.Field1__c</field>
        <readable>true</readable>
        <editable>true</editable>
    </fieldPermissions>
    <fieldPermissions>
        <field>Ordering_Account__c.Field2__c</field>
        <readable>true</readable>
        <editable>true</editable>
    </fieldPermissions>
    <!-- Repeat for all fields in Ordering_Account__c -->
</PermissionSet>
```

Replace `Field1__c`, `Field2__c`, etc., with the actual field names for each object. Repeat the `<fieldPermissions>` block for each field within the respective objects. This will ensure that the system administrator has read and write access to all fields in all the specified objects.

Here is an example of how you can add these permissions:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<PermissionSet xmlns="http://soap.sforce.com/2006/04/metadata">
    <label>System Administrator</label>
    <objectPermissions>
        <object>Patient__c</object>
        <allowCreate>true</allowCreate>
        <allowDelete>true</allowDelete>
        <allowEdit>true</allowEdit>
        <allowRead>true</allowRead>
        <modifyAllRecords>true</modifyAllRecords>
        <viewAllRecords>true</viewAllRecords>
    </objectPermissions>
    <fieldPermissions>
        <field>Patient__c.Field1__c</field>
        <readable>true</readable>
        <editable>true</editable>
    </fieldPermissions>
    <fieldPermissions>
        <field>Patient__c.Field2__c</field>
        <readable>true</readable>
        <editable>true</editable>
    </fieldPermissions>
    <!-- Add more field permissions as needed -->
    <objectPermissions>
        <object>TestOrder__c</object>
        <allowCreate>true</allowCreate>
        <allowDelete>true</allowDelete>
        <allowEdit>true</allowEdit>
        <allowRead>true</allowRead>
        <modifyAllRecords>true</modifyAllRecords>
        <viewAllRecords>true</viewAllRecords>
    </objectPermissions>
    <objectPermissions>
        <object>Treating_Physician_Information__c</object>
        <allowCreate>true</allowCreate>
        <allowDelete>true</allowDelete>
        <allowEdit>true</allowEdit>
        <allowRead>true</allowRead>
        <modifyAllRecords>true</modifyAllRecords>
        <viewAllRecords>true</viewAllRecords>
    </objectPermissions>
    <objectPermissions>
        <object>Ordering_Account__c</object>
        <allowCreate>true</allowCreate>
        <allowDelete>true</allowDelete>
        <allowEdit>true</allowEdit>
        <allowRead>true</allowRead>
        <modifyAllRecords>true</modifyAllRecords>
        <viewAllRecords>true</viewAllRecords>
    </objectPermissions>
    <!-- Add field permissions for each field in the objects -->
</PermissionSet>
```

Replace `Field1__c`, `Field2__c`, etc., with the actual field names from the `Patient__c` object. You can add as many `<fieldPermissions>` elements as needed to cover all fields in the `Patient__c` object.

response.value:

Here are the field permissions based on the fields listed in the `Patient__c` object:

```xml
<fieldPermissions>
    <field>Patient__c.Accept</field>
    <readable>true</readable>
    <editable>true</editable>
</fieldPermissions>
<fieldPermissions>
    <field>Patient__c.CancelEdit</field>
    <readable>true</readable>
    <editable>true</editable>
</fieldPermissions>
<fieldPermissions>
    <field>Patient__c.Clone</field>
    <readable>true</readable>
    <editable>true</editable>
</fieldPermissions>
<fieldPermissions>
    <field>Patient__c.Delete</field>
    <readable>true</readable>
    <editable>true</editable>
</fieldPermissions>
<fieldPermissions>
    <field>Patient__c.Edit</field>
    <readable>true</readable>
    <editable>true</editable>
</fieldPermissions>
<fieldPermissions>
    <field>Patient__c.List</field>
    <readable>true</readable>
    <editable>true</editable>
</fieldPermissions>
<fieldPermissions>
    <field>Patient__c.New</field>
    <readable>true</readable>
    <editable>true</editable>
</fieldPermissions>
<fieldPermissions>
    <field>Patient__c.SaveEdit</field>
    <readable>true</readable>
    <editable>true</editable>
</fieldPermissions>
<fieldPermissions>
    <field>Patient__c.Tab</field>
    <readable>true</readable>
    <editable>true</editable>
</fieldPermissions>
<fieldPermissions>
    <field>Patient__c.View</field>
    <readable>true</readable>
    <editable>true</editable>
</fieldPermissions>
<fieldPermissions>
    <field>Patient__c.Patient_Name__c</field>
    <readable>true</readable>
    <editable>true</editable>
</fieldPermissions>
```

Add these field permissions to the `Admin.profile-meta.xml` file to ensure the System Administrator can read and write all fields in the `Patient__c` object.

Here is an example of how you can define these permissions in the [`Admin.profile-meta.xml`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2Fforce-app%2Fmain%2Fdefault%2Fprofiles%2FAdmin.profile-meta.xml%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/thbui/Documents/Salesforce/Order-Management-System/force-app/main/default/profiles/Admin.profile-meta.xml") file:

 Error parsing file: Element {http://soap.sforce.com/2006/04/metadata}label invalid at this location in type Profile (3:12)

parts.text: for
#file:Admin.profile-meta.xml

facing this error:
 Error parsing file: Element {http://soap.sforce.com/2006/04/metadata}label invalid at this location in type Profile (3:12)

response.value:
The error indicates that the `<label>` element is not valid at its current location within the `<PermissionSet>` element. The `<PermissionSet>` element should not contain a `<label>` element. Instead, it should contain elements like `<objectPermissions>` and `<fieldPermissions>`.

To fix this, you should remove the `<label>` element from the `<PermissionSet>`.

response.value:
The error indicating that the module cannot be found could be due to several reasons. Here are some steps to troubleshoot and resolve the issue:

1. **Check the Apex Class**:
   - Ensure that the [`QueryController`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2F.sfdx%2Ftypings%2Flwc%2Fapex%2FQueryController.d.ts%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A0%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D ".sfdx/typings/lwc/apex/QueryController.d.ts") Apex class exists in your Salesforce org.
   - Verify that the [`searchAccounts`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2F.sfdx%2Ftypings%2Flwc%2Fapex%2FQueryController.d.ts%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A1%2C%22character%22%3A2%7D%5D ".sfdx/typings/lwc/apex/QueryController.d.ts") method is defined as `@AuraEnabled` in the [`QueryController`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2F.sfdx%2Ftypings%2Flwc%2Fapex%2FQueryController.d.ts%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A0%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D ".sfdx/typings/lwc/apex/QueryController.d.ts") class.

2. **Check the Import Path**:
   - Ensure that the import path is correct. The path should match the exact namespace and class name in Salesforce.

3. **Check Deployment**:
   - Make sure that the [`QueryController`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2F.sfdx%2Ftypings%2Flwc%2Fapex%2FQueryController.d.ts%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A0%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D ".sfdx/typings/lwc/apex/QueryController.d.ts") class has been deployed to the org where you are running the JavaScript code.

4. **Check Permissions**:
   - Ensure that the user running the JavaScript code has the necessary permissions to access the [`QueryController`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2F.sfdx%2Ftypings%2Flwc%2Fapex%2FQueryController.d.ts%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A0%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D ".sfdx/typings/lwc/apex/QueryController.d.ts") class and the [`searchAccounts`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2F.sfdx%2Ftypings%2Flwc%2Fapex%2FQueryController.d.ts%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A1%2C%22character%22%3A2%7D%5D ".sfdx/typings/lwc/apex/QueryController.d.ts") method.

5. **Check for Namespace**:
   - If your Salesforce org uses a namespace, ensure that the namespace is included in the import path.

6. **Check for Compilation Issues**:
   - Sometimes, Salesforce might not compile the Apex class correctly. Try saving the [`QueryController`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2F.sfdx%2Ftypings%2Flwc%2Fapex%2FQueryController.d.ts%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A0%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D ".sfdx/typings/lwc/apex/QueryController.d.ts") class again in the Developer Console or your IDE.

Here is an example of how the [`QueryController`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2F.sfdx%2Ftypings%2Flwc%2Fapex%2FQueryController.d.ts%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A0%2C%22character%22%3A0%7D%5D ".sfdx/typings/lwc/apex/QueryController.d.ts") class should look:

```apex
public with sharing class QueryController {
    @AuraEnabled
    public static List<Account> searchAccounts(String searchTerm) {
        // Your implementation here
    }
}
```

If everything seems correct and the issue persists, try the following steps:

1. **Clear Cache**:
   - Clear the cache and hard reload the page in your browser.

2. **Re-deploy the Apex Class**:
   - Re-deploy the `QueryController` class to ensure it is correctly deployed.

3. **Check for Typos**:
   - Double-check for any typos in the import statement or the Apex class name and method.

By following these steps, you should be able to identify and resolve the issue with the import statement.

response.value: Let's verify if the variables used in the `lightning-input` and `lightning-datatable` components in the HTML file match the `@track` variables in the JavaScript file. ### JavaScript: [`orderForm.js`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2Fforce-app%2Fmain%2Fdefault%2Flwc%2ForderForm%2ForderForm.js%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/thbui/Documents/Salesforce/Order-Management-System/force-app/main/default/lwc/orderForm/orderForm.js") #### @track Variables ```javascript @track patientSearchTerm = ''; @track patients; @track patientError; patientColumns = [ { label: 'First Name', fieldName: 'FirstName__c', type: 'text' }, { label: 'Last Name', fieldName: 'LastName__c', type: 'text' }, { label: 'Date of Birth', fieldName: 'DOB__c', type: 'text' }, { label: 'Sex', fieldName: 'Sex__c', type: 'text' }, { label: 'Middle Initial', fieldName: 'MI__c', type: 'text' }, { label: 'Address', fieldName: 'Address__c', type: 'text' }, { label: 'City', fieldName: 'City__c', type: 'text' }, { label: 'State', fieldName: 'State__c', type: 'text' }, { label: 'Zip', fieldName: 'ZipCode__c', type: 'text' } ]; ``` ### HTML: `orderForm.html` Ensure that the `lightning-input` and `lightning-datatable` components use the correct variables. #### Example of `lightning-input` ```html ``` #### Example of `lightning-datatable` ```html ``` ### Steps to Verify 1. **Check `lightning-input`**: Ensure that the `value` attribute of `lightning-input` matches the `@track` variable `patientSearchTerm`. 2. **Check `lightning-datatable`**: Ensure that the `data` attribute of `lightning-datatable` matches the `@track` variable `patients` and the `columns` attribute matches the `patientColumns` array. ### Example HTML Code ```html ``` ### Summary - Ensure that the `value` attribute in `lightning-input` is bound to [`patientSearchTerm`](command:_github.copilot.openSymbolFromReferences?%5B%7B%22%24mid%22%3A1%2C%22fsPath%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2Fforce-app%2Fmain%2Fdefault%2Flwc%2ForderForm%2ForderForm.js%22%2C%22external%22%3A%22file%3A%2F%2F%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2Fforce-app%2Fmain%2Fdefault%2Flwc%2ForderForm%2ForderForm.js%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2Fforce-app%2Fmain%2Fdefault%2Flwc%2ForderForm%2ForderForm.js%22%2C%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%7D%2C%7B%22line%22%3A133%2C%22character%22%3A4%7D%5D "force-app/main/default/lwc/orderForm/orderForm.js"). - response.value:
The error "LIKE operator only valid on string field" suggests that one or more fields in your SOQL query are not of type `String`. The fields you are querying against (`FirstName__c`, `LastName__c`, `Email__c`, `NPI__c`) must all be of type `String` for the `LIKE` operator to work.

To debug this issue, you should:

1. Verify the data types of the fields in your Salesforce schema.
2. Ensure that all fields used in the `LIKE` clause are of type `String`.

Here is the relevant part of your SOQL query in [`force-app/main/default/classes/QueryController.cls`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2Fforce-app%2Fmain%2Fdefault%2Fclasses%2FQueryController.cls%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/thbui/Documents/Salesforce/Order-Management-System/force-app/main/default/classes/QueryController.cls"):
```cls
'FirstName__c LIKE :physicianSearchTerm OR LastName__c LIKE :physicianSearchTerm OR Email__c LIKE :physicianSearchTerm OR NPI__c LIKE :physicianSearchTerm';
```

### Steps to Fix:

1. **Check Field Types in Salesforce Schema:**
   - Ensure that `FirstName__c`, `LastName__c`, `Email__c`, and `NPI__c` are all `String` fields.

2. **Modify the Query if Necessary:**
   - If any of these fields are not `String`, you will need to either change the field type in Salesforce or adjust your query to only include `String` fields.

### Example of Correct Query:
Assuming all fields are of type `String`, your query should work as expected. If any field is not a `String`, you need to remove it from the `LIKE` clause or convert it to a `String` type.

### Example of Adjusted Query:
If `NPI__c` is not a `String`, you might adjust your query like this:
```cls
'FirstName__c LIKE :physicianSearchTerm OR LastName__c LIKE :physicianSearchTerm OR Email__c LIKE :physicianSearchTerm';
```

### Verify and Update Field Types:
1. Go to Salesforce Setup.
2. Navigate to the Object Manager.
3. Select the object that contains `FirstName__c`, `LastName__c`, `Email__c`, and `NPI__c`.
4. Check the field types and ensure they are `String`.

### Update the Apex Class:
If you need to adjust the query, update the [`QueryController.cls`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2Fforce-app%2Fmain%2Fdefault%2Fclasses%2FQueryController.cls%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/thbui/Documents/Salesforce/Order-Management-System/force-app/main/default/classes/QueryController.cls") file accordingly.

If all fields are confirmed to be `String` and the issue persists, please provide more details about the field types or any additional error messages you encounter.

followups.message: How can I handle searching for facilities by name and address in Salesforce using Apex?

response.value:
To include `facilityColumns` and `facilityFieldMapping` based on the provided `Ordering_Account__c` extraction, you can define these mappings and columns as follows:

### Updated [`OrderTestHandler.cls`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2Fforce-app%2Fmain%2Fdefault%2Fclasses%2FOrderTestHandler.cls%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/thbui/Documents/Salesforce/Order-Management-System/force-app/main/default/classes/OrderTestHandler.cls")

```apex
// Define facility columns
List<String> facilityColumns = new List<String>{
    'FacilityName__c',
    'Address__c',
    'ZipCode__c',
    'City__c',
    'State__c',
    'Country__c',
    'Phone__c',
    'Email__c'
};

// Define facility field mapping
Map<String, String> facilityFieldMapping = new Map<String, String>{
    'orderingFacilityName' => 'FacilityName__c',
    'orderingAddress.street' => 'Address__c',
    'orderingAddress.postalCode' => 'ZipCode__c',
    'orderingAddress.city' => 'City__c',
    'orderingAddress.province' => 'State__c',
    'orderingAddress.country' => 'Country__c',
    'orderingPhone' => 'Phone__c',
    'orderingEmail' => 'Email__c'
};

// Extract ordering facility information
Ordering_Account__c orderingFacilityInfo = new Ordering_Account__c(
    FacilityName__c = (String) input.get('orderingFacilityName'),
    Address__c = (String) ((Map<String, Object>) input.get('orderingAddress')).get('street'),
    ZipCode__c = (String) ((Map<String, Object>) input.get('orderingAddress')).get('postalCode'),
    City__c = (String) ((Map<String, Object>) input.get('orderingAddress')).get('city'),
    State__c = (String) ((Map<String, Object>) input.get('orderingAddress')).get('province'),
    Country__c = (String) ((Map<String, Object>) input.get('orderingAddress')).get('country'),
    Phone__c = (String) input.get('orderingPhone'),
    Email__c = (String) input.get('orderingEmail')
);
System.debug('orderingFacilityInfo: ' + orderingFacilityInfo);
```

### Summary

- `facilityColumns` is a list of the fields in `Ordering_Account__c`.
- `facilityFieldMapping` is a map that associates input keys to the corresponding fields in `Ordering_Account__c`.

This setup ensures that you have a clear mapping and list of columns for the `Ordering_Account__c` object.

The provided excerpt from the [`Patient__c.object-meta.xml`](command:_github.copilot.openRelativePath?%5B%7B%22scheme%22%3A%22file%22%2C%22authority%22%3A%22%22%2C%22path%22%3A%22%2FUsers%2Fthbui%2FDocuments%2FSalesforce%2FOrder-Management-System%2Fforce-app%2Fmain%2Fdefault%2Fobjects%2FPatient__c%2FPatient__c.object-meta.xml%22%2C%22query%22%3A%22%22%2C%22fragment%22%3A%22%22%7D%5D "/Users/thbui/Documents/Salesforce/Order-Management-System/force-app/main/default/objects/Patient__c/Patient__c.object-meta.xml") file defines the metadata for the `Patient__c` custom object in Salesforce. However, it does not include field-level security or permissions for specific profiles, such as the System Administrator.

To ensure that the System Administrator can see all fields in the `Patient__c` object, you need to configure the field-level security in the profile settings or permission sets. This is typically done through the Salesforce UI or by defining the permissions in a profile or permission set metadata file.

### Example: Profile Metadata for System Administrator

Here is an example of how you might define the field-level security for the System Administrator profile in a profile metadata file:

```xml
<Profile xmlns="http://soap.sforce.com/2006/04/metadata">
    <fieldPermissions>
        <editable>true</editable>
        <field>Patient__c.FieldName__c</field>
        <readable>true</readable>
    </fieldPermissions>
    <!-- Repeat <fieldPermissions> for each field in the Patient__c object -->
    <objectPermissions>
        <allowCreate>true</allowCreate>
        <allowDelete>true</allowDelete>
        <allowEdit>true</allowEdit>
        <allowRead>true</allowRead>
        <modifyAllRecords>true</modifyAllRecords>
        <object>Patient__c</object>
        <viewAllRecords>true</viewAllRecords>
    </objectPermissions>
</Profile>
```

### Example: Permission Set Metadata

Alternatively, you can use a permission set to grant access to all fields in the `Patient__c` object:

```xml
<PermissionSet xmlns="http://soap.sforce.com/2006/04/metadata">
    <fieldPermissions>
        <editable>true</editable>
        <field>Patient__c.FieldName__c</field>
        <readable>true</readable>
    </fieldPermissions>
    <!-- Repeat <fieldPermissions> for each field in the Patient__c object -->
    <objectPermissions>
        <allowCreate>true</allowCreate>
        <allowDelete>true</allowDelete>
        <allowEdit>true</allowEdit>
        <allowRead>true</allowRead>
        <modifyAllRecords>true</modifyAllRecords>
        <object>Patient__c</object>
        <viewAllRecords>true</viewAllRecords>
    </objectPermissions>
</PermissionSet>
```

### Steps to Configure in Salesforce UI

1. **Go to Setup**: Log in to Salesforce and go to Setup.
2. **Profiles**: Navigate to Profiles and select the System Administrator profile.
3. **Object Settings**: In the profile settings, go to Object Settings and select the `Patient__c` object.
4. **Field Permissions**: Ensure that all fields are set to visible and editable as needed.

By configuring the field-level security and object permissions, you can ensure that the System Administrator has access to all fields in the `Patient__c` object.
